Equations (Vacation Planning)

Mission 08: Equations Vacation

[SYSTEM NOTIFICATION] A D-Rank Gate has been detected. Difficulty: Real-World Application. Hunter, prepare to plan an expedition using mathematical strategy!

The Challenge Awaits

Young Hunter, every successful raid requires planning. Before Hunters enter dangerous Gates, they calculate costsâ€”equipment, supplies, transportation, lodging. Today, you'll practice these essential skills by planning a family expedition to Orlando!

Variables become real when money is involved. Learn to track dependent and independent variables, and you'll never overspend on a dungeon raid.

âš”ï¸ Hunter's Arsenal (Gear Checklist)

Gather these exact items before entering the Gate: - Family Vacation Planning worksheet (or blank paper) - Paper and pencil for each team member - Internet access for research

ğŸ¯ Mission Objectives

Upon completion of this Gate, you will have unlocked: - Variable Relationships - Use variables that change in relationship to one another (6.EE.9) - Equation Writing - Write equations showing dependent variables in terms of independent variables (6.EE.9) - Data Visualization - Use graphs and tables to show relationships (6.EE.9)

ğŸ“– The Hunter's Knowledge (Brain Download)

Independent vs. Dependent Variables

Independent Variable: The thing YOU control (the input) Dependent Variable: The thing that CHANGES based on your choice (the output)

Example: Hotel Cost

Independent: Number of nights (you choose this)
Dependent: Total cost (this depends on nights)

If 1 night = $100:
2 nights = $200
3 nights = $300

The total DEPENDS on the number of nights.

Writing Equations with Variables

Let n = number of nights
Let c = total cost
Price per night = $100

Equation: c = 100 Ã— n

If n = 5:
c = 100 Ã— 5 = $500

Making a Table

Nights (n) Cost (c = 100n)
1 $100
2 $200
3 $300
4 $400
5 $500

Video Lessons: - Dependent and Independent Variables (6.EE.9) - Expressions with Variables | CK-12 Foundation - Making Tables and Graphs | CK-12 Foundation

ğŸ—¡ï¸ The Quest (Activity)

ğŸ“œ Verbatim Instructions:

Together: Pretend we are planning a trip to an amusement park in Orlando, Florida. Which amusement park would you like to go to? Research what parks you can visit. What do you need to plan if you want to go on a trip? Discuss: How will we get there? How do we get around once we are there? Where will we stay? What will we eat? What time of year should we go? Is it cold or hot? Does it get colder at night? How late is the park open?

Help solve problems on the Family Vacation worksheet. Then take the final total and divide by either 6 or 12 months to see how much the family would need to save each month to go on this vacation. They may be able to decide to change some of the activities too.

Extension: If your family wants to plan a family vacation somewhere else, work together to decide how much it would cost to go to the other location.

Phase 3: Calculate Monthly Savings

To save for this trip:

Total Cost Ã· 12 months = Monthly Savings

Example:
$2,400 Ã· 12 = $200 per month

Or faster (6 months):
$2,400 Ã· 6 = $400 per month

Phase 4: Write Your Equation

Let m = number of months
Let s = amount saved per month
Let T = total needed

Equation: T = s Ã— m

If you need $2,400 and save $200/month:
2,400 = 200 Ã— m
m = 12 months
